Lignin derived hierarchical porous carbon with extremely suppressed polyselenide shuttling for high-capacity and long-cycle-life lithium–selenium batteries Pengfei Lu a 1 Fangyan Liu a b 1 Feng Zhou a b Jieqiong Qin a c Haodong Shi a c Zhong-Shuai Wu a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 Liaoning China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China b Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 Liaoning China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shijingshan District, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Shijingshan District Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, 19 A Yuquan Rd, Shijingshan District, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian 116023 Liaoning China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract A low-cost scalable strategy is developed to fabricate lignin derived hierarchical porous carbon as a high-loading Se host. When combined with carbonate-based electrolyte, the high-capacity and long-term cycling Li–Se batteries were obtained. Lithium–selenium (Li–Se) batteries have attracted considerable attentions for next-generation energy storage systems owing to high volumetric capacity of 3265 mAh cm−3 and excellent electronic conductivity (~10−5 S cm−1) of selenium. However, the shuttling effect and capacity fading prevent their wide applications. Herein we report a low-cost strategy for scalable fabrication of lignin derived hierarchical porous carbon (LHPC) as a new high-loading Se host for high-capacity and long-term cycling Li–Se batteries in carbonate electrolyte. The resulting LHPC exhibits three-dimensional (3D) hierarchically porous structure, high specific surface area of 1696 m2 g−1, and hetero-atom doping (O, S), which can effectively confine the Se particles into the micropores, and meanwhile, offer effective chemical binding sites for selenides from hetero-atoms (O, S). As a result, our Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC demonstrate high capacity of 450 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C after 500 cycles, with a low capacity fading rate of only 0.027%. The theoretical simulation confirmed the strong affinity of selenides on the O and S sites of LHPC effectively mitigating the Se losing. Therefore, our strategy of using lignin as the low-cost precursor of hierarchically porous carbon for high-loading Se host offers new opportunities for high-capacity and long-life Li–Se batteries. Keywords Lignin Hierarchical porous carbon Lithium selenium battery Long cycling stability Energy storage 1 Introduction As an emerging high-capacity cathode material for Li batteries, selenium (Se) behaves much higher conductivity of 1 × 10−3 S m−1 and almost the same volumetric capacity of 3265 mAh cm−3, compared with sulfur (5 × 10−28 S m−1, 3467 mAh cm−3) [1]. Importantly, the shuttle effects of polyselenides are much weaker than those of polysulfides in Li-S batteries [2–5]. Therefore, Li–Se batteries present a broad prospect in portable electronics, hybrid electric vehicles and renewable energy storage systems [6–10]. However, the shuttle effect, large volume expansion of Se electrode and low utilization of bulk Se in the cathode are still the bottleneck issues, which greatly prevent their applications. To overcome this, several key strategies such as confining selenium in carbon hosts [11–19], adsorption and catalytic conversion of polyselenides by transition metal compounds (e.g., CoS2, MoSe2, TeSe x , ZnSe, ZnO, SnO, TiO2, Fe2O3) [20–27], designing nanoporous or nanofibrous selenide cathodes [28–30], constructing Se based hybrids (S, polyaniline, polyacrylonitrile, graphene) [31–35], and adding the interfacial blocking layers (e.g., conductive carbon, graphene, polyacrylonitrile) [36–39] between the cathode and separator, were developed for high-performance Li–Se batteries. Among them, confining Se powder within diverse carbon matrix (e.g., porous carbon nanospheres [11] and nanofibers [12], microporous carbon [13], mesoporous carbon [14], hierarchical porous carbon [15,16], graphene [17], multi-walled carbon nanotube [18]) is considered as the most prevailing approach to efficiently minimize the shuttle effect of polyselenides and maintain high electrical conductivity of cathode. In particular, porous carbon is one highly competing electrode material for Se cathode, not only because of its superior electrical conductivity and large internal surface, but also the confinement of carbon framework which can immobilize the Se particles and increase the cathode stability. Therefore, developing the desirable porous carbon is the premise for high-performance Li–Se batteries. For instance, Huang’s group [11] developed a Se wrapped porous carbon nanospheres as cathode with a high Se loading about 70.5 wt% for Li–Se battery, exhibiting outstanding rate capability, e.g., keeping 57% of the theoretical capacity (675 mAh g−1) at 20 C and excellent cycling stability over 1200 cycles with a capacity decay as low as 0.03% per cycle. Li’s group [16] fabricated hierarchical porous carbon spheres derived from metal-organic frameworks for the Se host of Li–Se battery, exhibiting an initial capacity up to 588.2 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and outstanding cycling stability over 500 cycles with a decay rate of 0.08% per cycle. Besides, Guo’s group [17] confined chain-like Se n into a highly graphitic carbon nanosheet for Li–Se batteries, showing highly reversible capacity of 650 mAh g−1 and long cycle life (1000 cycles) at 0.5 C, owing to the synergistic combination of rich micropore and mesopores. Despite of great advances of Li–Se batteries, the raw materials of porous carbons are usually expensive, and their synthesis procedures are not highly flexible and scalable. The rational construction of low-cost hierarchical porous carbon for the Se hosts that can effectively immobilize Se/selenide species, and exceptionally suppress polyselenide shuttling for high-performance Li–Se batteries remain elusive. To this goal, herein we develop a universal one-step, scalable strategy for the fabrication of low-cost lignin derived hierarchical porous carbon (LHPC) as a new high-loading Se host for high-capacity and long-term cycling Li–Se batteries. The LHPC, produced by a temperature-controlled annealing of the kraft lignin at 400 °C and 700 °C, displayed three-dimensional (3D) framework, hierarchical micro/meso/macroporous structure, large specific surface area of 1696 m2 g−1, and S, O hetero-atoms doping, which was advantageous for the stable Se host. Consequently, Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC cathode demonstrated excellent cycling stability, showing higher capacity of 460 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C after 500 cycles, with a retention of 92%, corresponding to an extremely low capacity fading rate of only 0.027%. Further, density functional theory (DFT) calculations uncoiled the strong affinity of selenides on the O, S sites, which effectively mitigated shuttle phenomena. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The kraft lignin was bought from Wuhan East China Chemical CO., LTD, China and was used as supplied. The hydrochloric acid (36 wt%~38 wt%) was bought from Shenyang Economic and Technological Development Area Reagent Factory, Shenyang, China. The selenium powder (99.9% metals basis) and commercial porous carbon (CPC, micro/mesoporous carbon with specific surface area of ~2000 m2 g−1) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation, Shanghai, China. All the chemicals were directly used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of LHPC and Se@LHPCs For the preparation of LHPC, the kraft lignin was directly pyrolyzed in a tubular furnace first at 400 °C for 1 h (2 °C min−1) and then heated at 700 °C for 1 h (4 °C min−1) under Ar atmosphere. After cooling down to the room temperature, the black product was rinsed with 1 M HCl solution to eliminate the inorganic salts and subsequently the ultrapure water until pH was close to neutral. Finally, the LHPC was collected after drying at 120 °C for 8 h. To load Se into LHPC, the as-obtained LHPC and Se powder were thoroughly mixed (1:2 in mass ratio) by ball-milling process. Then, the mixture was kept at 260 °C for 10 h and 350 °C for 1 h in an enclosed glass tube under Ar atmosphere to facilitate the diffusion and encapsulation of melted selenium into the pores of LHPC. Finally, the resultant Se@LHPC composite was collected as cathode for Li–Se batteries. For comparison, the counterpart of Se encapsulated by CPC (denoted as Se@CPC) was prepared by the same procedure of Se@LHPC. 2.3 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of as-synthesized samples were collected by using Empyrean equipped with Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) with the 2θ ranging from 10° to 70°. Morphology and elemental compositions were characterized by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7800F), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM-2100) with an EDX detector. The chemical components of LHPC and Se@LHPC were explored by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-α) operated at 200 kV, and analyzed using Avantage software. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, NETZSCH STA 449 F3) was conducted to acquire the content of Se in Se@LHPC under a N2 atmosphere. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were acquired with the aid of micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument to obtain the BET specific surface areas and pore size distributions of LHPC and CPC, respectively. 2.4 Cell assembly and electrochemical measurements For the fabrication of Se cathode, the obtained Se@LHPC or Se@CPC (initial C/Se mass ratio is 1:2) was combined with Ketjen black (conductive agent) and sodium alginate (binder) with a mass ratio of 8:1:1 and milled into the slurry with deionized water. The slurry was blade cast onto the carbon-coated Al foil, and dried in the oven at 55 °C for 12 h. The mass loading of Se in the cathode is ~0.47 mg cm−2. The dried cathode was punched into the discs of 12 mm in diameter for assembling cells, Combined with polypropylene (PP) separator, Li foil anode (0.5 mm in thickness), and electrolyte, Li–Se batteries were assembled using CR2016 coin cells in a Ar-filled glove box. We used 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 v/v), and 1.0 M LiTFSI and 0.1 M LiNO3 in 1,3-dioxolane (DOL)/1, 2-dimethoxymethane (DME) (1:1 v/v) as the carbonate-based and ether-based electrolytes, respectively. The amounts of electrolytes used for each cell were about 60 μL for carbonate and 50 μL for ether electrolytes, respectively. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) test was carried out on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation at scan rates of 0.1 mV s−1 within 1.0–3.0 V versus Li+/Li for carbonate-based batteries and 1.7–3.0 V for ether-based batteries. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were obtained using a CHI 660D workstation by applying an AC amplitude of 5 mV over the frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Galvanostatic charge and discharge (GCD) profiles were tested with a LAND CT2001A battery tester. Moreover, the Se@LHPC with the initial LHPC/Se mass ratio of 1:4 (Se mass loading of 1.17 mg cm−2), and 1:1 (Se mass loading of 1.67 mg cm−2) were also used for cycling performance test. 2.5 Density functional theoretical calculations The adsorptions of Li2Se on pristine carbon (C), O-doped carbon (OC), S-doped carbon (SC) and O, S dual-doped carbon (OSC) were calculated and compared. All the calculations were performed by using the Dmol3 software [40] in the framework of density functional theory (DFT) [41,42]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) combined with the Perdew–Burke–Enzerhof (PBE) functional was employed to describe the exchange and correlation potential [43,44]. The structural relaxations of C, OC, SC and OSC models were carried out firstly, followed with the adsorption simulation step. All the atoms of the calculated systems were allowed to fully relax in order to optimize the adsorption geometries. A double-numerical basis with polarization functions (DNP) was utilized to expand the valence electron functions into a set of numerical atomic orbitals. For the convergence thresholds, the minimum allowed energy change between the two adjacent iterative steps was set to 1 × 10−5 Ha, and the tolerance of force was 2 × 10−5 Ha Å−1. Based on Monkhorst-Pack method [45], the Brillouin zone integration was sampled with 8 × 8 × 1, 10 × 1 × 1 and 1 × 1 × 1 k-point grids for C, OC/SC/OSC and Li2Se models, respectively. The distance of vacuum space was set to 20 Å and the long-range dispersion correction was considered via Grimme’s scheme. The adsorption energy (E) was defined as the energy difference between the substrate model with the adsorbed molecule (E total) and the summation of the adsorbed molecule (E 1) and substrate system (E 2): E = E total – (E 1 + E 2). 3 Results and discussion The fabrication of Se@LHPC cathode for Li–Se batteries was schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . First, the kraft lignin was directly pyrolyzed at 400 °C for 1 h and thus for 700 °C for 1 h under Ar atmosphere. Second, the pyrolyzed product was rinsed with 1 M HCl solution, and subsequently washed by the ultrapure water and dried to obtain LHPC. Finally, the Se@LHPC hybrid was obtained by a melt-diffusion process by loading Se into LHPC at 260 °C for 10 h and 350 °C for 1 h under Ar atmosphere. The structure and morphology of as-obtained LHPC and Se@LHPC were characterized by SEM, TEM, XRD, and TGA techniques. The SEM images of LHPC (Figs. 2 a, b and S1) show a 3D honeycomb-like microporous interconnected network, which is highly favorable for the loading of elemental Se inside. TEM images further present the disordered, amorphous carbon with microporous and mesoporous structure of LHPC (Fig. 2c and d). For the Se@LHPC composites, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping images display the uniform distribution of selenium into the heteroatom (S, O)-doped hierarchically porous carbons. Notably, heteroatom (S, O)-doped sites from LHPC would provide effective various chemical binding sites for selenides to enhance the adsorption of selenides [46]. Importantly, LHPC displays a type IV curve with a H4-type hysteresis loop (Fig. 3 a) [47], and exhibit high specific surface area of 1696 m2 g−1, The hierarchical porous structure is also confirmed by the pore-size distribution profile (Fig. 3b), showing the enriched micropores of 1.5 nm, and also abundant large mesopores (20–50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm), which can provide sufficient space to accommodate and tightly confine Se8 molecules inside. The hierarchical porous structure is also confirmed by the pore-size distribution (Fig. 3b), showing the enriched micropores of 1.5 nm, abundant mesopores (20–50 nm) and large macropores (>50 nm) [48]. For Se@LHPC, TGA curve discloses that the amount of Se is 52% and 70% in Se/LHPC hybrids when the initial Se/LHPC ratio is 2:1 and 4:1, respectively (Fig. 3c). Such loading amount of Se is well comparable to the recently reported works, usually below 60% [48–51]. It is worth noting that the loss temperature begins at 400 °C, which is higher than the sublimation point of Se (260 °C), indicating the volatilization of Se is effectively inhibited by carbon framework. The XRD pattern of LHPC shows a broad peak between 20° and 30°, suggestive of the formation of amorphous carbon. Further, the peaks at 2θ of 23.5°, 29.7° and 43.6°, which correspond to the (1 0 0), (1 0 1) and (1 0 2) planes of Se crystal (JCPDS card no. 06-0362), are also observed from Se@LHPC, indicative of the successful hybridization (Fig. 3d). Therefore, based on the discussions above, it is confirmed that the Se species are effectively wrapped and spatially confined in hierarchically porous carbon framework of Se@LHPC. Since the selection of proper electrolyte is a key parameter to control the shuttling of polyselenides, we firstly assembled Li–Se batteries based on LHPC in carbonate-base electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate (1:1 v/v) and ether-based electrolyte (1.0 M LiTFSI and 0.1 M LiNO3 dissolved in the mixed solvent of DOL and DME with a volume ratio of 1:1), and compared the effect of carbonate-based and ether-based electrolytes on the battery performance (Fig. 4 ). Notably, Li–Se batteries working in carbonate-base electrolyte display the initial and third discharge capacities of 796 and 459 mAh g−1, respectively, and stay almost the same in the following cycles. While in ether-based electrolyte, the initial and third discharge capacities are 821 and 494 mAh g−1, respectively, and continually decrease to 140 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles. This big disparity can be attributed to the dissolubility difference of polyselenide intermediates in different electrolytes. In addition, the only discharge platform for the carbonate electrolyte means the formation of polyselenide intermediates are basically completely suppressed in the carbonate electrolyte (Fig. 4a) because of the insolubility of the polyselenides, and the whole reaction only involves the transition of solid selenium to solid Li2Se in the cathode [52,53]. In a sharp contrast, there are two voltage platforms in the discharge profiles for ether-based electrolyte. It is indicated that the soluble polyselenides are largely formed from the transition of Se8 (Fig. 4c), which are unavoidably permeated into the electrolyte during the charge/discharge processes, leading to serious shuttling effect and fast capacity degradation [54,55]. The similar phenomenon also can be observed for Se@CPC cathode in carbonate and ether-based electrolytes (Figs. S2, S3). Therefore, it is demonstrated that the carbonate electrolyte is highly benefit for high-capacity, stable-cycling and long-lifetime Li–Se battery and thus is applied in the following studies. To demonstrate the superiority of hierarchical micro/meso/macroporous structure of LHPC over the micro/mesoporous structure of CPC (Figs. S4, S5), we further examined the electrochemical performance of Se@LHPC cathode and Se@CPC cathodes for Li–Se batteries with potential window of 1.0–3.0 V versus Li+/Li in carbonate based electrolyte (Fig. 5 ). The galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of Se@LHPC and Se@CPC cathodes obtained at 0.5 C in the third cycle were compared. Interestingly, both of them exhibit one flat voltage plateaus displayed in all discharge curves, corresponding to the one step conversion mechanism from Se to Li2Se [2]. However, Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC cathode show a smaller polarization voltage of 0.33 V than that of Se@CPC cathode (0.50 V), indicative of improved kinetics. Importantly, Li–Se batteries with Se@LHPC cathode exhibit higher capacity of 500 mAh g−1 than that of Se@CPC (300 mAh g−1) at the same rate (0.5 C) and display better rate capability (Fig. 5b and c). It can be seen that the corresponding discharge capacities of Se@LHPC cathode are as high as 575, 429, 375, and 332 mAh g−1 when the current density is switched at 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, respectively. When the current density is switched to 0.2 C again, the capacity can return to 429 mAh g−1. However, the capacities of Se@CPC cathode are much lower at each current density, i.e., 311 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 218 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, 171 mAh g−1 at 1 C, 125 mAh g−1 at 2 C, and 262 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, respectively (Fig. 5c). This value of 575 mAh g−1 (0.2 C) for Se@LHPC is much higher than those of most reported Li–Se batteries based on graphene (265 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C) and carbon nanotube (504 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C) [56,57]. Fig. 5(d–f) displays the cycling stability and Coulombic efficiency of Se@LHPC and Se@CPC cathodes for Li–Se obtained at 0.5 C for 500 cycles. When the LHPC serves as the Se host, the initial capacity is ~834 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and becomes stable at ~450 mAh g−1 from the second to the 500th cycles. The capacity retention is as high as 92%, corresponding to an extremely low capacity fading rate of only 0.027%. While for Se@CPC cathode, the capacity only retained 180 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles, and the capacity retention is only 60% with a fast capacity fading rate of 0.13%. In addition, the Se@LHPC cathode also shows more stable Coulombic efficiency (nearly 100%) than those of Se@CPC (oscillating between 90% and 110%). The improved performance is attributed to the hierarchical porous structure of LHPC which can efficiently accommodate the electrolyte in the macropores and physically confine Se element inside the micro/mesopores. To demonstrate the importance of hierarchical porous structure, the performances of Se@LHPC and Se@CPC for Li–Se batteries were further explored by CV measurements (Fig. 6 a, b). For Se@LHPC cathode, one broad reduction peak in the first cycle appears at ~1.5 V, standing for the conversion of Se8 to Li2Se and the formation of solid electrolyte interface layer [51]. In the next two cycles, the reduction peaks shift to 1.75 V. The oxidation peak at ~2.1 V indicates the oxidation of Li2Se to Se during the charge process [58]. The well-overlapped curves after 2nd cycle demonstrate outstanding electrochemical reversibility of Se@LHPC for Li–Se batteries. While for Se@CPC, there are also one oxidation peak and one reduction peak appearing in the CV curves. The oxidation peak at ~2.1 V represents the phase change from Li2Se to Se, and the reduction peak at 1.5–1.7 V is assigned to the reaction of Li and Se into Li2Se [58]. It is worth noting that the broad reduction peak at ~1.5 V for the first cycle shifts to ~1.7 V and become narrower in the subsequent cycles. The potential difference between the oxidation peak and reduction peak (0.4 V) is larger than that in Se@LHPC cathode (0.35 V), suggesting slow redox kinetics in Se@CPC cathode. Further, the EIS plots of Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC and Se@CPC cathodes were measured before and after cycling (Figs. 6c and S6). Before cycling, both of them display a semi-circle in high frequency range connected with an inclined plot in low frequency range. Differently, Se@LHPC shows lower charge-transfer resistance of 86 Ω, in comparison with Se@CPC (>143 Ω). While after 50 cycles, the charge-transfer resistance sharply decreased to ~10 Ω for Se@LHPC, which is still much lower than that of Se@CPC (~40 Ω). This can be explained by the synergy of hierarchical micro-/meso-/macropores in LHPC, which is favorable for the rapid electrolyte penetration and fast Li diffusion [59]. Moreover, the long-term cycling performances of Se@LHPC cathodes with different Se mass loading of 0.47 mg cm−2 and 1.17 mg cm−2 were compared in Fig. 6(d). Impressively, both of them present the excellent cycling stability at 0.5 C, with highly stable capacities of about 460 mAh g−1 and 400 mAh g−1, respectively. It is noted that even with high Se mass loading of 1.67 mg cm−2, Se@LHPC cathode can display more than 470 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C (Fig. S7). What’s more, such Se mass loading and cycling stability are well comparable to other Se hosts reported (Tables S1 and S2) [50,51,58–61]. Besides, the element components of LHPC (Fig. 7 a–c) and Se@LHPC (Fig. S7) were disclosed by XPS. The C 1s spectrum of LHPC shows three fitted peaks corresponding to CC (284.8 eV), CS (286.5 eV), and CO (288.8 eV) (Fig. 7a), indicative of O and S doping [62]. The high-resolution O 1s spectrum is resolved into the peaks of OC, OS, and CO3 at 533.4, 535.8, and 531.2 eV, respectively [48]. For S 2p XPS spectrum, it is deconvoluted into three peaks of SO (168.5 eV), SC (165.1 eV), and SS (164.0 eV) (Fig. 7b and c) [63,64]. The atomic ratios of S and O are 1.14% and 8.37%, respectively. For Se@LHPC, Se element is detected except C, O, and S elements (Fig. S8a–c). The Se 3d spectrum (Fig. S8d) clearly displays two major peaks of Se 3d5/2 (55.3 eV) and Se 3d3/2 (56.0 eV) [49]. To get further insight into the structure-performance relationship between the doped heteroatoms (O, S) and electrochemical properties, the DFT calculations were conducted to model the adsorption of Li2Se on pristine carbon (C), O-doped carbon (OC), S-doped carbon (SC) and O, S dual-doped carbon (OSC), respectively. The optimized geometries and the corresponding adsorption energies of different adsorption models are displayed in Fig. 7(d). It is disclosed that the molecules are apt to bind with edge atoms at the carbon substrates, especially when O, S atoms are existed. The adsorption energies between Li2Se and C, OC, SC, and OSC are calculated to be −3.03 eV, −4.76 eV, −4.09 eV, and −4.20 eV, respectively. It is revealed that the O, S dual-doping can significantly increase the chemical affinity between Li2Se and carbon substrate, and effectively prevent the generation of selenides during the charge/discharge processes. Therefore, the presence of heteroatoms in LHPC would further boost the capacity and cyclability of Li–Se batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrated a general one-step, inexpensive strategy for scalable fabrication of heteroatom-doped LHPC as a Se cathodic host for high-performance Li–Se batteries. Owing to the unique 3D hierarchically porous structure, large specific surface area, high micropore volume and hetero-atom doping (O, S), LHPC can be used as a high-loading Se host with improved selenides anchoring for high-capacity and long-term cycling Li–Se batteries in carbonate electrolyte. The Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC exhibit higher capacity than the counterpart of Se@CPC, and significantly enhanced columbic efficiency and rate capability, highlighting the superiority of hierarchically porous structure. Impressively, Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC demonstrate excellent cycling stability, showing an extremely low capacity fading rate of only 0.027% per cycle. What’s more, the O, S hetero atoms on LHPC are computationally confirmed to bind the selenides by strong chemical adsorptions, which could effectively mitigate the Se losing during charge and discharge processes. Therefore, this strategy of fabricating low-cost LHPC with hierarchical porous structure will pave the way to develop high-performance Li–Se batteries, Li-S batteries, and other metal-Se/S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium–selenium (Li–Se) batteries have attracted considerable attentions for next-generation energy storage systems owing to high volumetric capacity of 3265 mAh cm−3 and excellent electronic conductivity (~10−5 S cm−1) of selenium. However, the shuttling effect and capacity fading prevent their wide applications. Herein we report a low-cost strategy for scalable fabrication of lignin derived hierarchical porous carbon (LHPC) as a new high-loading Se host for high-capacity and long-term cycling Li–Se batteries in carbonate electrolyte. The resulting LHPC exhibits three-dimensional (3D) hierarchically porous structure, high specific surface area of 1696 m2 g−1, and hetero-atom doping (O, S), which can effectively confine the Se particles into the micropores, and meanwhile, offer effective chemical binding sites for selenides from hetero-atoms (O, S). As a result, our Li–Se batteries based on Se@LHPC demonstrate high capacity of 450 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C after 500 cycles, with a low capacity fading rate of only 0.027%. The theoretical simulation confirmed the strong affinity of selenides on the O and S sites of LHPC effectively mitigating the Se losing. Therefore, our strategy of using lignin as the low-cost precursor of hierarchically porous carbon for high-loading Se host offers new opportunities for high-capacity and long-life Li–Se batteries.
